section.title: Determinants and volumes
section.p: It turns out that determinants are actually an instance of something you already know about: volume. Specifically, the n many columns of a square n\times n matrix A are all vectors in \mathbb R^n. These n vectors determine a parallelepiped in \R^n, which we will call the parallelepiped for A. In particular, if n=2, then we obtain a parallelogram. For example, if A is a 2\times2 matrix whose columns are non-zero vectors v and w, that is, if A=\spalignmat{v; w}, then we have the parallelogram determined by v and w:

figure.caption: The parallelgram determined by two vectors v_1 and v_2 in \R^2

section.p: Similarly, if A is a 3\times3 matrix, then we obtain three vectors in \R^3, which define a parallelepiped:

figure.caption: The parallelepiped determined by three vectors in \R^3

paragraphs.title: Key Observation
paragraphs.p: The matrix A is invertible if and only if the parallelepiped for A has non-zero volume, i.e., if and only if the parallelepiped is not "flat".

section.p: This is not too hard to believe, especially in low-dimensional cases. For example, if A is a 2\times2 matrix whose columns are non-zero vectors v and w, then we know that the matrix is invertible exactly when v and w are linearly independent, which happens exactly when they don't lie on the same line (neither is a scalar multiple of the other). But this occurs exactly when the parallelogram for A in isn't "squashed."
This type of thinking leads us to the following fact.

fact.p: The determinant of a n\times n matrix with rows v_1,\ldots,v_n is \pm1 times the volume of the parallelepiped spanned by the vectors v_1,\ldots,v_n in \mathbb R^n.

proof.p: Why should be true? Well, we saw in that the properties of having the value 1 on the identity matrix and satisfying the properties of uniquely determine the determinant. Thus, you just have to check that the volume of the parallelepiped for a matrix A is also a function on square matrices which satisfies these properties. Firstly, re-scaling a row of a matrix by a constant multiple re-scales the parallelepiped by that multiple in the direction of the corresponding row vector. In particular, you can think of that row as being the one giving the height of the parallelepiped, the base doesn’t change, but the height gets scaled by the same amount you scaled the row. Swapping rows swaps the ordering of the sides of the parallelepiped, but this just changes labelling, and hence doesn't change volume, while in the determinant it only changes the volume by a fator of \pm 1 (technically, the determinant give the signed volume of the parallelepiped with a fixed ordering on the row vectors; this is similar to the signed area you saw that integrals give in calculus). Moreover, if you perform a row replacement on a matrix changes neither the base nor the height of the corresponding parallelepiped (thinking of the replaced row as giving the height), and so the volume is left the same, as is the determinant. Finally, the parallelepiped for the identity matrix is the unit n-dimensional cube, which has volume 1=\det I_n.

section.p: For example, if n=1 and A=\spalignmat{a}, we can think of 1-dimensional "volume" as length, and the "parallelepiped for A" is just the vector a in \R^1. Moreover, the length of this vector is |a|, which is \pm a=\pm\det A.

In the case of a 2\times2 matrix A=\mat{a b; c d}, we have \det A =ad-bc. It may seem that this formula has little to do with volume. However, it is a fun geometry problem to show that the parallelogram for A in has area |ad-bc| (first think about the case when the first column of A lies on the x-axis). As another fun problem, one can perform row reduction directly on A to find that the reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix I_2 exactly when ad-bc\neq0 (although we omit the calculation here).

Now suppose that T_A\colon\mathbb R^n\rightarrow\mathbb R^n is the linear transformation associated to an invertible n\times n matrix A. We think of T_A as some operation that you do to \mathbb R^n. We’ve seen examples of this before, for instance when T_A is a reflection, a projection, a rotation, a stretch or a shear. Of course, in general, T_A can be some complicated combination of these.
What does T_A do to \mathbb R^n? It turns out that it transforms finite-volume regions in \mathbb R^n to regions with predictable volumes.

fact.p:
If T_A is a linear transformation of \mathbb R^n associated to an n\times n matrix A and S is a region in \mathbb R^n, then
\text{volume}(T_A(S))=|\det A\,|\cdot\text{volume}(S).

section.p: Why should this be true? Well, we know that T_A takes the standard basis vectors e_1,\ldots,e_n to the columns of A. It follows that the standard unit cube spanned by e_1,\ldots,e_n gets taken to the parallelepiped spanned by the columns of A. What is the volume of this parallelepiped? Well, since \det A = \det A^T (can you see why?),the volume of the parallelepiped is |det A| by . In summary, T_A changes the volume of the standard cube by det A. Now we know something about what T_A does.

Actually, we know more. If we take the cube \varepsilon e_1,\ldots, \varepsilon e_n where \varepsilon is a small real number (wait, are we doing Calculus now?), then since T_A is linear, the image of this cube—which has (signed) volume \varepsilon^n—will have volume \left|\det A\varepsilon^n\right|. What does that buy us? Well now take any shape S in \mathbb R^n that has finite volume. Fill it as best you can with \varepsilon-cubes. The total volume of the \varepsilon-cubes is approximately volume(S). Now apply T_A. What is the volume of T_A(S)? We just said that each of the little cubes gets its volume stretched by \det A. Since that’s true, all of S gets its volume stretched by \det A.
Let's illustrate this in a visual example in \mathbb R^2
For curvy shapes, the idea described above it the usual one from calculus; you break S up into a bunch of tiny cubes. Each one is scaled by |\det A|.
